replies.commentText: +Elle McMasters Funny, but also a good point. The mansion (especially the cellar) is like a decaying womb, the walls dripping with menstrual blood - the corridors look like part of a Venus Flytrap. Yet it's all so GORGEOUS. This really is a feminine movie, a battle between light and dark female forces, with a tragic male caught in the middle. http://c8.alamy.com/comp/CNY84J/venus-flytrap-venuss-flytrap-venus-flytrap-venus-fly-trap-venuss-fly-CNY84J.jpg
+92ninersboy The fading beauty and fortunes of his victims. I didn't have as much sympathy for him as you seem to have. He seemed anything but caught in the middle. He seemed the responsible party.

+Elle McMasters He WAS responsible, he had participated in terrible acts - but he was both a predator and a victim. Thomas was caught up in his dark family history and was controlled by Lucille, but he did have a creative side and when he met Edith he discovered he had fallen in love with her and so he had to face Lucille with the truth (which cost him dearly). Thomas was caught between the force of light (Edith) and the force of darkness (Lucille) - he chose the light.

This is a great film, but it is not a horror movie. This is a Gothic romance that focuses on the opposing forces of the Victorian period, the Industrial Revolution and the desire to return to a quasi medieval period. This is a quintessential example of what the Romantic movement was all about: strong emotions, a desire to live i a world full of mystery instead of scientific reason. It's also a great ghost story.

For those of you who have not seen Crimson Peak here is my review: Neither a gothic romance nor a gothic horror 'Crimson Peak' lacks thrills, chills or surprises of any kind. Strangely predictable it is festooned with cheesy CGI ghosts and great silvery moths that flutter through the great masoleum of a house (get out the moth balls!). While you cannot fault the actors (they are excellent) even their thespian talents are incapable of salvaging a hopelessly muddled script. If only Del Toro had brought in a Stephen King or a Tom Clancey type for re-writes. Oh well.

This is not a film for modern audiences accustomed to cheap horror gimmicks like Paranormal Activity, Annabelle, or Ouija. This is a throwback movie and love letter to classic gothic horror like the films of Mario Bava, Dario Argento, Hammer horror films, the old dark house subgenre, and classic gothic literature like Edgar Allan Poe plus many other inspirations. Like most of Del Toro's work, the true horror of the story is not supernatural, but people themselves. As a fan of the classics, this movie was amazing!

commentText: Just watched the movie earlier today--a gothic horror (f'd up) romance film that's actually pretty good; It's well-directed, love the soundtrack, very nice cinematography (the way they shot the mansion was really cool), pretty good acting, didn't expect Loki from the Avengers in this film; And the story...well...starts out slow, has some cheap jumpscares from the overly CGI-d ghosts, but it does redeem itself in the second half when the twists unfold and you see who the villains really are--that last half hour was pretty f'd up. It's worth a viewing in the theaters for sure, as the movie's truly meant to be seen on the big screen. Just go for the $6 Tuesday movie ticket when you can. Del Toro, I didn't want to, but I wound up loving most of your work. Now you've lost me. This trailer is mismarketed and so is this film. It is NOT a 'gothic romance' and it is NOT a 'horror' or a 'thriller'. It just dances back and forth between elements of the three as if you had written all three complete stories in mind and just wound up making aesthetics, NOT the house itself, a key player. You don't even introduce us to the grounds in an ominous enough way or pull out great performances, either. You talked about this being an empowering film for women and it is the opposite of that. There are no clear villains or victims and while that worked in a film like The Devil's Backbone and The Golden Army, it does not work here. We want Hiddleston to be an all-out monster or a hero, not rape-bully and the same is true for the rest of this powerful cast; you got Alice, Loki, and a Jaeger Pilot and used them to form the flimsiest love triangle since The . . . so that was YOU that did that in The Hobbit! The metaphor between butterflies and moths is not nearly as dark as you think, either. It actually seems silly in this setting. While I think this has a place in film like 'Sleepy Hollow' was a Tim Burton film strictly this could be seen as strictly a Del Toro style of film; but are bloodlust for land from our protagonists (that's right, industrialists were just that, not heroic and selfless in the majority of their cases Carnegie was a once in a lifetime guy) and constant undertones of incest that have been building in your films really what you want the world to associate with you? I would've written the ending to show at least a photograph of Edith's mother courting Thomas to hint at either immortality through keeping the house and the two are desperate for that reason as well as isolated, or to find out that Edith's mother is cousin to the Sharpe family and that gives her a bloodlink that allows her to remove that dishonor from the family name. And why wasn't the ghost of her father looking out for her as well? Do you not believe in male ghosts for their own sake, just women's? If Edith could just 'see ghosts' and was not simply intuitive the way an unexplained Stephen King child gets telepathy, then why was she not 'seeing dead people' much, much more unless she could pinpoint her father telling her to ignore them or something? You had an interesting idea, but like so many people in art galleries you only got in a few pieces and didn't take in the depth of the whole exhibit. I think what Stephen King really found scary about your film was its budget, not the story. It's The Fall of the House with The Seven Flowers in the Attic. If you read, you'll be able to see how many disappointing ripoffs were given such a superficial picture. Some people might find this amusing, but I don't think you're sure of the group of messages that will be taken from it and that's not what an artist's approach to expression is.

+Kirsten Hoppins I see the ending as this: After a long time fighting with her inner psyche, and coming to terms with her therapist (can't remember his name) being the manipulating sadist he was, she strengthened her own psyche. You can see Wonderland in the beginning as a terrible place, full of disaster, and in the ending it's like a peaceful fungi forest. Wonderland now seems like a much better place. If you look at some of the last word Cheshire Cat says ‚ÄùForgetting pain is convenient. Remembering it, agonizing. But recovering the truth is worth the suffering. And our Wonderland, though damaged, is safe in memory‚Ä¶ for now.‚Äù. Here Wonderland is Alice's mind, She was ignorant, but somewhat happy (convenient, right?). After she discovered the truth, hell broke loose. It was a time full of disaster (agonizing?). But she pulled through, and overcame her enemy, the therapist (worth the suffering?), and is now safe (Wonderland, though damaged, is safe in memory). In short I think it symbolizes how she overcame her ignorance and pulled through, and is now enlightened and stronger. If you've seen "Alice: Otherlands (I think it's called)", you can see that Alice has concurred her own mind, and now enters the minds of others. Through her "torture" she's come through victoriously, strong enough enter the minds of others (it can be a symbol though). In the Alice: Otherlands, she says she was afraid of fire (her family?), but isn't anymore. She's overcome her own fear, and is stronger than ever. Sorry for the long reply, but I think it's REALLY interesting! I could go on several hundred lines more, but let's stop here XD

So after more viewings, I figured out how the brother and sister are immortal. At 1:16 you see these large locked tubs in the room. At 1:18, you see the board of the tub push up, meaning there is something locked in there. At 2:01 you see the contents of this one tub, a dead body. But not just any dead body, the body looks to be digested, missing skin and bones, also notice the red goo it is in. Drowned bodies bloat and retain their skins. So the brother and sister kill or trap people then put them in the tubs for the house to eat or digest, giving the brother and sister long life or immortality. Very nice-ah.

Oh, I unraveled the plot with enough viewings. The brother and sister are immortal or long lived. They kill people as a sacrifice of some type to keep their immortality. One of the previous victims, the ghost with the longer hair, died in the bathtub which you see at 1:58. The ghost with the long hair, is the mother of the blond girl, whom has been watching over her, protecting her, since she was a baby, which is why she says she has been seeing ghosts all her life. What ties the Blond woman and the ghost with the long hair together, is the baby picture the Blond woman finds at 1:45. The blond woman was there in the past as a baby from the long haired ghost; the male killer is a potential father of hers. Very good story, can't wait to see it.

Spoiler: The ghost with the long hair is actually trying to save the blond girl from the other ghosts and the brother sister killers. It's been watching over her since she was a child as you see at the end, it even warns her about Crimson Peak.

I love Guillermo Del Toro and much of the body of work he's done. He's very stylized and has a very distinct stamp that he leaves on all of his movies. Some have not been up to par, but for the most part they've all been wonderful. I did find this trailer a bit underwhelming. I've heard much buzz surrounding Crimson Peak and was interested to see the trailer, but I wasn't feeling it. I do think much of it has to do with Mia Wasikowska. I've never been a fan of her's and I tend to lean toward the feeling that she drags down any film that she's in. She usually plays the same character and she doesn't add much life to any scene she's in, and while I hate to base my opinion of her character off a 2 1/2 minute trailer, it does seem like her typical thing. I really wanted to like this trailer. I just didn't. I perked up when I saw Tom Hiddleston but I just couldn't get passed my complete indifference to Wasikowska. I'd rather love her or hate her, but I just don't even care about her which is bad to me. She's like the female Brecken Meyer. They could both disappear and I just wouldn't care. Might go see it when it comes out. Man I really wanted to love this trailer!

replies.commentText: +Jordan Brown Too bad, Mia is one of the very best actors of her generation, she's amazingly talented - ask Cate Blanchett, Meryl Streep, Michael Fassbender, Nicole Kidman, Glen Close and many others, who have said the same. "Jane Eyre", "Stoker", "Tracks", "Only Lovers Left Alive", "In Treatment", I found her mesmerizing in all. Her talent is why so many great directors feature her in their films.

+92ninersboy I never said she wasn't talented. I merely stated my opinion on her performances. But just because you get work doesn't mean that you're talented. Kristen Stewart starred in a franchise and it's pretty much a universal agreement that she's awful. Same with Jai Courtney. I don't know how that guy keeps getting work. Mia could be really good, but I've yet to see her deliver a performance that made me leave the theater feeling that she blew me away. That's why I'm indifferent towards her. At the same time, she's 25 years old and all those actors and actresses are established people and they're not going to say anything bad about her. What the say is what they're expected to say. Again, I don't hate her. I don't love her either. I just don't care about her. Maybe she'll surprise me in this one. I would love it if she did.

+Jordan Brown DIfferent people have different reactions. Mia blew me away the first time I saw her years ago as Sophie on "In Treatment" - I immediately called up a friend to tell him about this new brilliant actress. When Meryl Streep accepted her Golden Globe, out of nowhere she brought up Mia's performance in "Jane Eyre" calling it "fantastic" (Mia wasn't there, and she hadn't been nominated - Meryl just wanted to sing her praises) this was NOT what she was expected to say. It's fine if you don't connect to Mia, but please realize there are many viewers, actors, and directors who do - she just doesn't happen to broadcast on your frequency, so you're not getting the message. That's fine, not everyone will. I'm incredibly excited about seeing Crimson Peak, for Del Toro, for Tom Hiddelston, and most especially, for Mia Wasikowska.

+Jordan Brown I can agree with you about Kristen Stewart but otherwise I have to go with +92ninersboy. I think Mia is extremely talented. I've seen five of her films and non of them were the same performance or character type. She's actually quite a versatile actress. Del Toro likened working with her to driving a Porche cause he could ask her to do different approaches and was totally happy with all the results. I like that she's not an over-acting, perky Hollywood actress. She is a very authentic actress with a nuanced intensity and emotion in her. Edward Zwick said, "her inner life is so vivid that it comes across even when she's being still." It seems that most that don't like her saw her in Alice In Wonderland. I didn't see Alice because it looked too froced and contrived. That includes Johnny Depp, Mia and the whole look of it. Maybe she wasn't a good fit, and it has left folks always seeing her as her Alice performance. Although some said she wasn't that bad. She got Alice at 19 and was considered an impressive, young artist out of Australia. She has mostly done quality indie films since or bigger serious films like Defiance and usually partnered with brilliant actors and directors (ie. Michael Fassbender, Edward Zwick ..). Crimson is her return to the big fantasy block buster, and she looks like she hitting the mark to me.

+Man of Miracles I respectfully disagree. Opinions CAN be wrong. They can be right if they're based on having the facts right - and they can be wrong based on having the facts wrong. Behold a demonstration: It's my opinion my neighbor's rooster is getting aggressive. That opinion is true, based on the fact that the stupid bird now chases and pecks the crap out of me. It's also my opinion that Frank Sinatra faked his death and will blow out the candles on his birthday cake this year. That opinion is wrong, because it's based on personal impressions and not on well thought out research, facts, or common sense. That opinion is invalid. I can have the opinion that Batman is cooler than Spider-man or that Halo is way better than Arkham Knight. You can't prove that's wrong or right because it's an opinion which can't be PROVED to be right or wrong. BUT!, I can have the opinion that Robin the Boy Wonder is really Spider-Man. +Daniel Mora Arrieta Yeah. You'd think by 1980 every writer would know that filmmakers take your book and need to turn it into THEIR film. Hemingway had that figured out in 1932! You can't do a five hour audio book just to make the writer happy. When King got around to doing "The Shining" the way he wanted to, it was over six hours long. I guess if Kubrick had made a six-hour-long film in 1980, King would've been happier! The thing is, even King messed around with the book. His version adds a sappy "10 years later" scene where the ghost of Jack looks on proudly as his little boy, Danny, graduates from High school. Aww, how sweet! It's sorta like Obi-Wan Kenobi - but stupid. Now, if Kubrick had tacked that on, King would've trashed the film. Oh, wait - that's what he did, anyway. Here's a funny side note: the Kubrick estate owned partial approval rights to any subsequent remakes of "The Shining." So, King had to get permission - from Kubrick! - to make his six hour epic. Here's the punchline: Kubrick said it was no problem - as long as King stopped trashing Kubrick's version. Now, THAT'S funny . . .! :)
+Qarcon Also! Roger Ebert says, "..."

+TheStockwell Well, damn, i didn't know all that story... So, ur telling me that King ruined his owned creation with some stupid spiritual FORCE thing, and in some way, Kubrick improved the story to end with that masterpiece? I guess that King is so proud and egocentric from all the legacy he has done, that he just gives a shit about any opinion to every effort that tries to give a cinematic version of his books... And by the way, i guess i learn something new today, THANKS man!!!

+Daniel Mora Arrieta I read the novel first. When I saw the film, it became clear Kubrick was making changes. Funny thing is - or maybe that was the point - because he wasn't following the novel page by page, I got scared because I didn't know what was coming next. If he had done a perfect adaptation, I would've sat there think, "Yeah. That was the way it was in the book. That, too. And that. Yawn" It's like Kubrick set out to make sure you freaked out by taking away all the fussy details of the novel you're expecting to see - and focusing on three people in a creepy, isolated place going nuts. I didn't miss the topiary hedge. I didn't miss the ongoing subplot of the boiler which had to be taken care of. I didn't miss Danny's three million conversations with "Tony." And I'm sure King wasn't angry about sales of his novel shooting up because Kubrick picked it up and thought, "You know, this would make a great film." They both rewrote the ending. Kubrick's ending is a brilliant WTF moment. King's finale is "Full House" style group hug - with a friendly ghost looking on! One thing's for sure: the stick up King's bum over Kubrick's film seems to be permanent. Despite some REALLY crappy adaptations of his writing, it's "The Shining" he won't stop bitching about. I'm sure his tombstone will read "Here lies Stephen King - The Master of Modern Horror Writers. He was born September 21st, 1947 and Stanley Kubrick really ruined "The Shining." If I were him, I'd be more obsessed with hunting down every copy of "Maximum Overdrive" - to make sure no-one ever sees it, again. :) Have a great week!
